answer_html: Thus the answer is 0.The splitting of the limit of a product into a product of limits is valid since the product is finite.
answer_latex:
Thus the answer is 0.The splitting of the limit of a product into a
product of limits is valid since the product is finite.
hints_html: Factor out the largest power of x in both the numerator and the denominator. Simplify and then see if you can take the limit.
hints_latex:
Factor out the largest power of \emph{x} in both the numerator and the
denominator. Simplify and then see if you can take the limit.
hints_raw: Factor out the largest power of ''x'' in both the numerator and the denominator. Simplify and then see if you can take the limit.
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
Following the hint, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{9x^{2}-6x + 8}{-3x^{3}+4} &= \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{x^{2}(9 - 6/x + 8/x^2)}{x^{3}(-3 + 4/x^3)} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{9 - \frac6{x} + \frac8{x^2}}{-3 + \frac4{x^3}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{1}{x}\cdot \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{9 - \frac6{x} + \frac8{x^2}}{-3 + \frac4{x^3}} \\ &= (0)\cdot \left(\frac{9}{-3}\right) = {\color{blue} 0}\end{aligned}\]

Thus the answer is 0. The splitting of the limit of a product into a product of limits is valid since the product is finite.
